Title:
Characterization of fungal species associated with cladode
brown spot in Nopalea cochenillifera in Brazil
Keywords:
aggressiveness, cladode disease, prickly pear cactus,
pathogenicity, phylogeny
Abstract:
Cladode brown spot is an important disease of Nopalea
cochenillifera in the semiarid region of Northeast Brazil. It has been
reported in several countries, but its etiology is controversial,
attributed to a complex of pathogens. Fifty fungal isolates were sampled
and identified for genus on the basis of morphology and phylogeny,
through analysis of ribosomal DNA internal transcribed spacers (ITS),
translation elongation factor 1- (EF1-), β-tubulin (TUB2), second
largest subunit of RNA polymerase (RPB2), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate
dehydrogenase (GPDH) and the apn2mat/IGS (ApMAT) genesequences.Seven
fungal genus and twenty species were identified - Alternaria: A.
gomphrenae, A. longipes A. tenuissima; Colletotrichum: C. fructicola and
C. siamense; Fusarium: F. lunatum,F. incarnatum, and F. verticillioides;
Lasiodiplodia: L. euphorbicola, L. iraniensis, L.pseutheobromae, L.
theobromaeandLasiodiplodiasp.; Neofusicoccum: N. batangarum;
Neopestalotiopsis: N. australis, N. protearum and
Neopestalotiopsissp.;and Nigrospora: N. sphaerica,
N.hainanensisandNigrosporasp.Fourof these species have already been
reported in cactaceae of the genus Opuntia, but only N. batangarum,C.
fructicola and C. siamenseare reported in the genus Nopalea. All
isolates were pathogenic to detached cladodes of
Nopaleacochenillifera(var. Miúda). Differences in aggressiveness were
observed among the species, with L.iraniensisandF. lunatumcharacterized
as the most aggressive species, whilst F.verticillioidesas the least
aggressive.
